items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

title.children: Prime Minister makes one last push for Yes, 5 million Australians have already cast their votes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Posting a photo of his completed ballot paper to X (formerly Twitter) late last week, one No voter may have had regrets after other users responded that he may have invalidated his vote. In a post implying that Australia's secret ballot system could be rorted, the user shared an image showing he had identified himself on his ballot paper by writing: "[Name redacted] voted 'no'. I am [name redacted]." But others should not follow his lead if they wish for their vote to be counted. As fellow X users quickly pointed out, guidelines published by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) suggest the man's vote would likely be counted as informal by polling officials. "If, in the opinion of the DRO (Divisional Returning Officer), there is sufficient writing on the ballot paper to uniquely identify the voter, the ballot paper is informal," the AEC guidelines state. Read more about the biggest debunked claims of the referendum below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why you shouldn't write your name on your referendum ballot paper

featuredLink.title: Don't do this to your ballot paper if you want your vote to count in the referendum

one No voter
may have had regrets after other users responded that he may have invalidated his vote.
In a post implying that Australia's secret ballot system could be rorted, the user shared an image showing he had identified himself on his ballot paper by writing:
"[Name redacted] voted 'no'. I am [name redacted]."
But others should not follow his lead if they wish for their vote to be counted.
As fellow X users quickly pointed out,
guidelines
published by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) suggest the man's vote would likely be counted as informal by polling officials.
"If, in the opinion of the DRO (Divisional Returning Officer), there is sufficient writing on the ballot paper to uniquely identify the voter, the ballot paper is informal," the AEC guidelines state.
Read more about the biggest debunked claims of the referendum below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The AEC has confirmed there will be more than 7,000 voting places open around Australia tomorrow. They'll be open from 8am to 6pm local time. Hit the link below to find a voting place near you.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What time does referendum voting open tomorrow?

children.content: The AEC has confirmed there will be
more than 7,000 voting places
open around Australia tomorrow.
They'll be open from

Hit the link below to find a voting place near you.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wani -Wandi man of the Yuin Nation and Black People's Union president Kieran Stewart-Assheton outlined the union's case for a No vote this morning on ABC News Breakfast. "The things is we have to understand there's a lot of false misrepresentations around the propaganda behind the Yes campaign. They talk about this being an invitation from First Nations people. But it's not an invitation from First Nations people," he said. Mr Stewart-Assheton said he hoped a No result on Saturday would mean "proper conversations" about "land rights, self-determination and sovereignty". But he said regardless of outcome, First Nations people had been "thrown under the bus" by the referendum. "It's still going to be detrimental for First Nations people. Either we're going to have a tokenistic advisory body which undermines our struggle or we'll end up with a racist outcome over what's deemed as a racist No. "Either way, First Nations people won't be helped by this referendum. We need to look beyond this referendum and look at organising properly to get some proper land rights and proper gains towards self-determination."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'First Nations people won't be helped by this referendum', says Black People's Union president

children.content: Black People's Union president Kieran Stewart-Assheton on ABC News Breakfast
(ABC News)
Wani -Wandi man of the Yuin Nation and Black People's Union president
Kieran Stewart-Assheton
outlined the union's case for a No vote this morning on ABC News Breakfast.

"The things is we have to understand there's a lot of false misrepresentations around the propaganda behind the Yes campaign. They talk about this being an invitation from First Nations people. But it's not an invitation from First Nations people," he said.
Mr Stewart-Assheton said he hoped a No result on Saturday would mean "proper conversations" about "land rights, self-determination and sovereignty".
But he said regardless of outcome, First Nations people had been "thrown under the bus" by the referendum.

"It's still going to be detrimental for First Nations people. Either we're going to have a tokenistic advisory body which undermines our struggle or we'll end up with a racist outcome over what's deemed as a racist No.

"Either way, First Nations people won't be helped by this referendum. We need to look beyond this referendum and look at organising properly to get some proper land rights and proper gains towards self-determination."

image.altText: GAZA ABC photo

items.synopsis: The death toll in Gaza is rising and vital supplies are running low. Follow live

title.children: PM confirms 19 Australians trying to flee Gaza, as death toll rises to more than 1,500

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says 19 Australians have reigstered themselves as trying to flee Gaza. "There is a family, for example, from Adelaide, of four, and we are having discussions with the Egyptian government about the potential to get them out into Egypt through that southern border," he tells ABC News Breakfast. "It's closed, of course, at the moment, formally, but we are having discussions to try to ensure that Australians can be gotten to safety. "We want all Australians to be safe in the region and be able to leave, whether they're in Israel or Gaza." The PM says 1,600 Australians are registered as being in the region of Israel, Gaza or the West Bank, but not all of them are necessarily trying to get out.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says 19 Australians are trying to flee Gaza

props.alt: Anthony Albanese in a suit and tie giving a TV interview outdoors near a jetty on the ocean

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says 19 Australians have reigstered themselves as trying to flee Gaza.

"There is a family, for example, from Adelaide, of four, and we are having discussions with the Egyptian government about the potential to get them out into Egypt through that southern border," he tells ABC News Breakfast.
"It's closed, of course, at the moment, formally, but we are having discussions to try to ensure that Australians can be gotten to safety.
"We want all Australians to be safe in the region and be able to leave, whether they're in Israel or Gaza."
The PM says 1,600 Australians are registered as being in the region of Israel, Gaza or the West Bank, but not all of them are necessarily trying to get out.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The death toll in Gaza has risen to 1,537, according to the Gaza Health Ministry. This includes 500 children and 276 women. It says 6,612 have been injured in Israeli air strikes on the blockaded enclave since Saturday. The Palestine Red Crescent Society says parademics have recorded 12 violations that resulted in the deaths of four paramedics and five others being injured. It says seven ambulances experienced damage and significant damage was inflicted on the association's headquarters in northern Gaza and the emergency operations room. Israel's public broadcaster Kan said the Israeli death toll had risen to more than 1,300. Most were civilians gunned down in their homes, on the streets or at a dance party.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll rises to more than 1,500 in Gaza, health ministry says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The prime minister has confirmed 220 Australians will be onboard the first Qantas plane scheduled to leave Israel in the early hours of Saturday morning. The plane is set to touch down in Tel Aviv late tonight before flying out in the early hours of tomorrow morning to London. Qantas will also send a second plane to Israel at a later date. The flights are available for Australian citizens who can't book a commercial ticket and are free of charge. Speaking on Channel Nine, Anthony Albanese says Qantas is now working out logistics to get Australians from London back home. "Qantas are also putting in place the logistical exercise to then fly from London back to Australia via Singapore, it's being put in place as we speak," he says. A third private charter flight has been organised for next week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First Qantas repatriation flight for Australians to arrive in Tel Aviv tonight

children.content: The prime minister has confirmed 220 Australians will be onboard the first Qantas plane scheduled to leave Israel in the early hours of Saturday morning.
The plane is set to touch down in Tel Aviv late tonight before flying out in the early hours of tomorrow morning to London.
Qantas will also send a second plane to Israel at a later date.
The flights are available for Australian citizens who can't book a commercial ticket and are free of charge.
Speaking on Channel Nine, Anthony Albanese says Qantas is now working out logistics to get Australians from London back home.
"Qantas are also putting in place the logistical exercise to then fly from London back to Australia via Singapore, it's being put in place as we speak," he says.
A third private charter flight has been organised for next week.

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". Read all about it as it happens on our live blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow. The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same. That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes. This note from CBA this morning: Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession. Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation and Israel-Gaza war sparks global recession concerns

featuredLink.title: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

children.content: Good morning!
The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow.
The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same.
That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes.
This note from CBA this morning:

Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession.
Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
